thread.title: Big-game hunting won’t help Africa’s rural poor

author: John Woodrow Cox
title: Big-game hunting won’t help Africa’s rural poor
text:
Elephants cross the road in Hwange National Park, in Zimbabwe. (Tsvangirayi Mukwazhi/Associated Press) October 20 at 5:53 PM In the Oct. 18 article “ Zimbabwe says elephant was killed in legal hunt ,” a spokesman for the Zimbabwe national parks agency — a government-run organization — and Louis Muller, president of the Professional Hunters and Guides Association, defended the killing of a huge elephant as a legal hunt that provided much-needed money for rural communities living near game reserves. By this bizarre reasoning, professional hunters (anyone who pays to kill big game) should be encouraged to do so to save rural communities from their corrupt, ruthless, incompetent, self-serving politicians.
Zimbabwean President Robert Mugabe and his cronies, in power for 35 years, have utterly destroyed the Zimbabwean economy and civil society, impoverishing millions while taking good care of each other. Now, professional hunters, with a lot of money, no conscience and expensive, high-power rifles, are like philanthropists, spending to help the rural poor by killing endangered wildlife.
Given the depths of corruption in government, in whose wild imaginings do ordinary people in rural areas benefit from this legally sanctioned slaughter?
Mark Addleson , Centreville
